Sï¿½ren Vejrup Carlsen wrote:
> Here are some questions:
> 
> In the Scope element, what does  max-trans-hops, and max-toe-threads mean?

max-trans-hops:

We consider certain discovered URIs to imply "transitive" inclusion:

  - embeds (such as IMG SRC and FRAME SRC)
  - referrals (redirections & refreshes)
  - prerequisites (DNS lookup and robots.txt fetch)

(Also, since our techniques for URI extraction from javascript are
crude, we currently always presume such URIs are embeds, because they
might be.)

"max-trans-hops" specifies how many such discoveries in a row will
still cause the URI to be included, even if is not otherwise inside
the defined crawl scope.

So, for example, if set at 3, and a page that is "in scope" has
an offscope frame, which includes another offscope frame, which
ncludes another offscope frame -- they will all be included. But an
embedded offscope image on that last frame is 4 transitive hops away,
and thus would not be included if the parameter is set at 3.

We're still experimenting with this notion, and how useful it
is to prevent wandering too far off scope (or down endless
crawler traps).

max-toe-threads:

The total number of Java Threads spawned to crawl URIs in parallel.

> I believe, that max-link-hops=10 should mean, that the crawler should only
> walk 10 steps away from a seed URL.

Yes.

> In the Processor  element, what does the Next component signify? Is this
> the next Processor to be activated?

Yes. In general, the Processors each specify a single next
Processor, but it is possible that some future custom Processors
might specify different next steps based on URI analysis.
(For example, "next-if-error" or "next-if-feature-X-detected".)

> Finally, in the Frontier element:
> <frontier
>      class="org.archive.crawler.basic.Frontier"
>      delay-factor="0"
>      minimum-delay="0"
>      maximum=delay="1000"
>     />
> what does the variables 'delay-factor', 'minimum-delay', and
> 'maximum-delay' signify?

These are all global politeness mechanisms, controlling the
amount of time between the completion of one URI (as reported back
to the frontier), and the frontier's release of the next URI
for that same host.

'minimum-delay' is the smallest wait-time allowable, specified
in milliseconds.

'delay-factor' is a multiple of the previous URI's elapsed time
to wait. So if it took 500ms to complete the last URI, and the
delay-factor is 2, the frontier will delay emitting the next URI
for the same host for 1000ms. (Unless the minimum-delay is higher
than 1000ms).

'maximum-delay' is a ceiling on how much of a delay to use,
specified in milliseconds. Even if the last URI took 3 seconds,
and the delay-factor is 2, suggesting a delay of 6 seconds,
if the maximum-delay is 2000ms, that maximum will be used.

- Gordon
